Here's a brand new update from our teams around the world working to stop the spread of #COVID19 on the front line of the pandemic: 

ðŸ‘ Our staff in Serbia helped install toilets in Obrenovac, an asylum center in Belgrade. The center is currently home to 1,200 people despite only having room for 300. Our team managed to carry out the government request in just 7 days. 
ðŸ‘ In Greece, IRC's Shadi is an Environmental Health Assistant and was part of the team who built a health triage center in Moria camp on the island of Lesvos. He is participating in a COVID-19 training led by MSF and will be looking after the environmental health on the islands such as managing garbage collection - safely. 
ðŸ‘ When the Venezuela border closed, many individuals became stuck at the Colombian border with Venezuela, waiting to cross through the irregular pathways. The IRC quickly assembled a team of nurses and doctors to do triage, as well as provide medical assistance to those with COVID symptoms and refer individuals according to the protocols established by the Colombian Ministry of Health. 
ðŸ‘ In Mexico, we have launched - together with local authorities and civil society partners - a public health awareness and psycho-social support campaign for people in shelters at the US-Mexico border in Ciudad JuÃ¡rez. The initiative will include sessions on transmission as well as protective and preventive measures, signs and symptoms of the virus, where to access help and support, reinforcement of public health best practices and the distribution of hygiene kits. 

So proud of our staff. Please join us in thanking all IRC health workers for their vital efforts combating the #coronavirus in crisis zones worldwide!

Women make history when they find each other. Especially this past year, they used our apps to connect and collaborate with one another. In this chapter of Women x Women, we asked Chrissie and Gladys Lam â€” a mother-daughter duo behind Love Is Project â€” to tell us what women supporting other women means to them and how that support has positively affected their lives.

Love Is Project partners with female artisans around the world to create unique bracelets that represent their culture and heritage. Every purchase means financial independence, water and food security for artisans and their families and education for their kids.

â€œTo be able to see the impact of our work is really inspiring â€” I get WhatsApp updates from artisans all the time. Weâ€™re seeing the improvements in these womenâ€™s lives, like having them be able to send their kids to school or build a community garden. So, our growth is exciting because we know weâ€™ll be able to touch and positively affect more lives.â€ - Chrissie Lam, CEO of Love Is Project

Join us in celebrating Womenâ€™s History Month by honoring powerful women in your life.

âœŠ Womenâ€™s rights activists in Uganda are taking down the patriarchy. âœŠ â â €
â â €
Meet some of these activists weâ€™re proud to work with as part of the IRCâ€™s Listen Up program with U.S. Department of State:  Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration - which aims to both listen *to* women and girls who are displaced (instead of deciding *for* them) and to amplify their voices - South Sudanese refugees and Ugandan change-makers are working together so that women and girls can live free from violence. â â €
â â €
âœŠ Jemimah Sadia, a refugee from South Sudan, is the founder of Togoleta, a womenâ€™s activist group in Bidi Bidi camp (the second largest in the world) that provides counseling to refugees in the camp to prevent violence and help women and girls recover from abuse. Building up her grass-roots womenâ€™s movement has been a huge part of her life since she found safety in Uganda.â â €
â â €
âœŠGrace Muuduru has been standing up for women since she was at school. She remembers confronting boys bullying her friend and telling them: â€˜One day this girl could be President!â€™ Today, she works for COSMESS, a womenâ€™s rights group in northern Uganda that helps both refugees and Ugandan women.â â €
â â €
âœŠ Jackie Letaru is a teacher in Uganda who challenges sexism in her classroom. â€œIâ€™m a feminist, a strong one,â€ she said. She cultivates a culture where girls know their value and are respected. â€œOne of my responsibilities at the school is being a leader to girls. Education is a key to their success.â€ â â €
â â €
âœŠ Foni Grace fled war in South Sudan to Uganda in 2016, taking her two daughters with her to Bidi Bidi camp. Today, sheâ€™s a member of Togoleta, the group founded by Jemimah (above). â€œMy work for women will be permanent. I feel I have to continue with my work in activism.â€ â â €
â â €
Women and girls, and particularly those living as refugees, are not passive recipients of humanitarian aid, but activists with their own ideas and motivations. At the IRC, we are proud to work alongside activists like Jemimah, Grace, Jackie and Foni to make equality a reality. â â €
â â €
